Gurugram: Pipe burst triggers water shor.description: GURUGRAM: Residents of DLF 1, 2, MG Road and sectors 27 and 43 complained of acute water crisis in their respective areas throughout the weekend, owing to a leak in the supply pipeline. Though officials from Gurugram Metropolitan Development Authority (GMDA) said that the issue has been resolved, residents alleged they are yet to receive water. Water supply has become an annual issue for the residents as every year during the summers the city witnesses a crisis.They said they did not receive water supply for two days, and alleged that for the last few days, supply has been limited and water pressure low. DLF 1 resident Dhruv Bansal said, “We did not receive any water from GMDA on Sunday. Though we were getting water for 30 minutes daily for the past three days, GMDA on Sunday completely snapped the supply.” DLF 1 resident Sunil Goswami said, “We are forced to buy water from private tankers and that is burning a hole in our pockets. A 4,000-litre water tanker costs Rs 1,500 at present. It is the responsibility of the department to provide us with alternatives in case they aren’t able to supply water through the usual pipeline.”For most part of this summer, residents have been uncoiling and hooking water hoses linking private water tankers parked outside their homes to tanks inside, replacing the water supply. In some sectors, residents have been forced to survive only on a few buckets of water. “I don’t think the authorities will be able to resolve the problem this year. We face this situation every year during the summers,” said Gyan Sharma, a resident of DLF 2. According to GMDA officials, supply was snapped at 7am on Saturday and restored at 10am on Sunday. Sandeep Dhaiya, executive engineer, GMDA, said, “We had to snap water supply in some parts of the city because of a leak in the pipeline near Signature Tower junction. Water supply was completely stopped for almost 26 hours. But it has been restored today.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Father's Day: Cannot cook or handle kids.description: Fathers can’t multitask, can’t cook, manage household chores along with their work, or can’t balance their professional lives with the personal ones – these are just some stereotypes that we have grown up hearing. But the new-age dads, who stay in nuclear as well as joint families, where both husband and wife are working, are not only dividing the task of raising kids equally, but also making sure that they are available for their kids for a heart-to-heart conversation, advice on friendships, or period talks. From taking leaves for kids’ exams to cooking and helping them with homework – things that one would typically expect a mother would do – are being done by dads quite well, who believe in not just sharing finances, but other responsibilities, too. On Father’s Day, we speak to some dads and mothers leading by example, who tell us about the stereotypes that fathers are subjected to, and how they are breaking them and contributing as an equal parent. Dads not emotional, says who?Ankur Gupta, a doctor and resident of Sector 50, Gurgaon, says, “Fathers are not sensitive, kids turn to their mothers if they want to express their feelings; fathers are messy, don’t help in household chores; they are not interested in school grades, and are uncomfortable in parent-teacher meetings – these are some common stereotypes that most fathers in India are subjected to. Thankfully, these are not applicable to me as at a very early age my daughter realised that she could walk up to me and talk about anything that is bothering her emotionally. I am also interested in knowing about what is happening in her school. There is no division of labour at our home but my wife and I know about the things we are good at, so we take the lead accordingly. I know I am good at language and my wife can manage the finances well, so it is like an unsaid rule that we follow to help our family in that way.” Tilak Chowdhury, a resident of Sector 169, Noida, who works at a consulting firm, adds, “The stereotypes are not restricted to just, dads can’t cook or look after the kids, often, they are also considered very strict and someone who cannot have fun, or show any emotion in front of their kids. Why can’t people expect a father to be like Anupam Kher’s character in Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge who can encourage his kids when they fail, or do not perform well in studies, or can discuss their love lives openly like Rishi Kapoor’s character in Hum Tum?” Can’t discuss heartbreaks with dads – seriously? You cannot discuss problems related to heartbreaks or seek advice after a fight with friends with your father as they won’t understand them – new-age dads are trying to break this stereotype. “We understand and can give useful advice to the kids. Why do people find it so difficult to accept that fathers can also have emotions and kids can have a conversation with us on topics related to heartbreaks or can seek any other emotional advice? I have always been available to my kids whenever they have wanted me. I remember that my elder daughter, now 15, would return disturbed from school. One day, I asked her about what was bothering her as I was concerned. I did not mean to interfere in her personal life, but I told her that she could come up to me whenever she was comfortable talk about it, and I would try to help her in all my capacity. It took her two days to tell me that she was facing problems with a friend, who would often fight with her on petty issues. I told her that it was important to focus on the friendship if it was important to them, they can fight over petty issues but school days won’t come back. We started with this topic and then she opened up about her school life and her friends from the neighbourhood. I was glad that she could tell me everything. That day, my daughter understood that she can discuss her problems with me and I will try to help her,” shares Arjun Singh, a businessman who lives in Rajouri Garden and father to two teenage daughters. Arpana Prakash, who runs a dance school, adds, “When I asked my seven-year-old daughter about who would she first tell about her boyfriend, and she said, ‘Dad.’ That is the comfort level that they share. We could never think about having a talk about menstruation with our fathers but today’s generation surely can.” ‘Can take care of kids and deal with clients’Raj Hazarika says that he is often asked why he willingly contributes as a homemaker. “This is something that they expect a woman to do but I like cooking and also enjoy doing it for my kids. Playing, cooking or just being with my kids is important as they are growing up, and this time will never come back. Raising kids is not an easy task, and there is nothing wrong in being equally involved with your partner in doing so. One has to adjust a lot while dealing with kids. I can manage my clients or colleagues easily but dealing with kids and their temperament is another thing – something that every parent should learn hands- on,” says Raj, a resident of Sushant Lok 2 who runs a coaching academy. For some, it is also a way to bond with their kids. “My wife is a teacher and she leaves around 6.30am, so I wake up early before my kids leave for school and pack their lunch. I leave for work around 10am, so I have enough time to spend with my kids. We both are working parents, so I don’t see it as a problem that I am cooking for my kids. When I come from work, my kids are often asleep because my wife is with them after school and helps them with the homework. If I have my Saturdays off, then I help them with their homework or extra-curricular activities but that is something I want to do as a parent, and not because somebody is forcing me to. People can think that I am too involved in my family but I am doing this because this is what I want to do,” says Roshan Sharma, a resident of Saket, who works as a consultant in a firm. In Video:Fathers battle stereotypes tooDownload The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Gurugram: Scientist \u2018harassed\u2019.description: GURUGRAM: A senior scientist at Forensic Sciences Laboratory (FSL) of Haryana Police in Madhuban has accused her boss — an official of the rank of additional director — of mentally and sexually harassing her. The complainant has claimed the harassment started last year, after she was posted at FSL, and has continued even after she was transferred to Gurugram on compassionate grounds on March 28, 2017. Acting on her complaint, the National Commission for Scheduled Castes issued a notice on June 7 to the state chief secretary and DGP, seeking an action taken report within the next 15 days. The complaint states the accused misbehaved with the complainant after calling her to his office, and when she resisted, he allegedly started harassing her to make her give in to his wishes. The complainant has accused other senior officials of pressuring her too, including an ADGP rank officer, accusing the latter of showing bias when she filed a complaint with him on September 27, 2018. On June 1 this year, she forwarded the same complaint to the Haryana DGP and the SC/ST commission, with the addition that in the meantime, a reader (sub-inspector rank) of the FSL director had tried to blackmail her, besides threatening a woman witness. As per her complaint, the department constituted two sexual harassment committees, both of which she claims did not follow guidelines. “A third committee was also formed, but I have so far not been asked to attend its hearings,” she wrote in her complaint, claiming she wants independent inquiry into her case, as all witnesses, who happen to be employees, are scared. “In her case, there was manipulation of inquiry and witnesses by the committee in favour of the accused, under pressure of the FSL director. I had earlier requested the committee to provide protection to witnesses, as per Supreme Court guidelines under its Witness Protection Scheme, 2018, but this was denied without advice and approval of the Haryana DGP. As witnesses were unwilling to come forward due to threats from the accused, I called and recorded statements of two witnesses, and submitted those in a CD, where they expressed strong fear of the FSL director. Twice already, the commission has issued notices to the state government, but nothing happened,” wrote the complainant. Following this, the SC/ST commission sent a notice to the Haryana chief secretary and DGP (copies are with TOI), demanding an action taken report. “It’s requested that present status/action taken report on the points raised in the representation may please be furnished to this commission within 15 days positively, for placing the same before the commission,” reads the notice. Haryana DGP Manoj Yadava said so far, he hasn’t received the notice. “The complaint is under investigation, but I can only speak on it once the inquiry is complete,” he said. BJP List 2019 Tamilnadu.description: CHENNAI: The BJP's Tamil Nadu candidates list announced on Thursday was on expected lines, with Union minister Pon Radhakrishnan being fielded from Kanyakumari, state chief Tamilisai Soundararajan in Tuticorin, national secretary H Raja in Sivaganga, C P Radhakrishnan in Coimbatore and vice-president Nainar Nagendran in Ramanathapuram. While Pon Radhakrishnan and Raja will fight Congress, which is yet to name candidates for its nine seats in DMK alliance, Tamilisai will cross swords with DMK heavyweight Kanimozhi in Tuticorin. H Raja to contest from Sivaganga for third timeH Raja is contesting from Sivaganga for the third time. In 2014, he came third with 1.33 lakh votes, while in 1999, he came second. It will be a keenly fought battle between Tamilisai and DMK’s state women wing secretary and Rajya Sabha MP K Kanimozhi in Tuticorin. Though Tamilisai initially preferred to contest from Chennai South, which has a sizeable votebank for the party, she finally settled for Tuticorin. AIADMK was keen on retaining south Chennai for sitting MP, J Jayavardhan, son of fisheries minister D Jayakumar. Former TN BJP chief Radhakrishnan will face CPM’s P R Natarajan in Coimbatore. This is the fifth time that Radhakrishnan has been fielded in Coimbatore, a BJP stronghold. While he won two consecutive Lok Sabha elections in 1998 and 1999, he was defeated in the 2004 and 2014 polls. Nainar Nagendran has been pitted against DMK’s IUML candidate K Nawaz Kani. While the party made a quick decision on candidates for four constituencies, Ramanathapuram delayed matters considering the keen contest for the seat among some senior leaders. Tamil Nadu Elections.description: Voting for Lok Sabha elections 2019 in Tamil Nadu will take place in a single phase on April 18 as per the notification issued by the Election Commission of India. The counting of votes will take place on May 23. | Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesThe four-cornered contest for the 39 Lok Sabha seats features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). Out of the 39 seats in the state, seven Lok Sabha seats are reserved for SC. The constituencies reserved for SC candidates are Thiruvallur, Kancheepuram, Villupuram, Nilgiris, Chidambaram, Nagapattinam and Tenkasi in Tamil Nadu. | Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesIn the last Lok Sabha polls, AIADMK had a vote share of 44.3 per cent by winning 37 seats. BJP had a vote share of 5.5 per cent by winning just 1 seat, while NDA managed to win two seats with a vote share of 18.5 per cent PMK won one seat and had a vote share of 4.4 per cent. BJP (NDA) had an alliance with PMK. DMK was not able to win on any seat in the last Lok Sabha polls. In Lok Sabha elections 2019, DMK is contesting on 20 seats, while the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Never a safe ride for cyclists in Gurugr.description: GURUGRAM: The accident near Signature Towers junction on Friday has again highlighted the city’s inadequate arrangements for pedestrians and cyclists on the roads. “Most of the roads in Gurugram have turned into national or state highways. If you look at the highway plan, no space is marked for cyclists and pedestrians, hence the roads in the city, too, lack the basic design. Also the inter-city roads are being widened every year but nothing has been done for the cyclists,” said Gurpeet Singh, a road safety officer. As per the data compiled by the Gurugram police, last year 35% accidents took place on the national highway, that divides the city into two halves. The data also points out that a total number of 475 fatalities took place in 2018. In 42% cases, the deceased were either cyclists or pedestrians. According to the experts the roads in Gurugram are not designed keeping in mind the safety of the pedestrians and the cyclists. With no proper partitions on roads for fast and slow moving vehicles, cyclists in Gurugram face huge challenges while commuting from one place to another. “We have lost many cyclists because of improper tracks. All the roads in the city are only designed for vehicles and also the people are very insensitive towards the cyclists which are the most important reasons that we can point out while speaking about the road safety issues,” said Abhishek Mishra, Ultraman, a resident of Gurugram. Manas Fuloria, chairperson of Nasscom Haryana chapter, said, “Roads in Gurugram are extremely scary when we talk about cyclists and pedestrians. There is a need to monitor the speed limits on roads and also separate slow and fast moving tracks. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Gurugram man shoots at friend for talkin.description: GURUGRAM: A 26-year-old man was arrested from his house in Bhangrola village on Saturday for allegedly shooting at a friend. The man was allegedly angry that his wife was receiving calls from the friend regularly. Rahul (24), who received a bullet injury on his left leg, told police, “Kapil and I have been friends for long. I reside in Baskushla village, while he along with his wife stayed in Bhangrola village. I used to talk to his wife over phone as I didn’t think it to be a big issue. On Saturday morning, Kapil asked me to meet him near my house. He was angry that I used to call up his wife. We had an argument, and suddenly Kapil took out a pistol and fired a shot at me.” After firing at Rahul, Kapil fled the spot. Locals rushed Rahul to a nearby hospital after making a PCR call. An FIR was registered against Kapil under Section 307 (attempt to murder) of the IPC at IMT industrial police station in Manesar. “Kapil was arrested from his house. He will be produced in court on Sunday,” said inspector Satbir Singh, SHO of IMT industrial police station. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Dairy business car snatched at gunpoint.description: AMBALA: Three miscreants snatched Vitara Brezza car from a Kurukshetra-based businessman at gunpoint on Ambala-Chandigarh road on Wednesday night. After receiving information, the district police reached the spot and started investigation. They have registered a case under the IPC and the Arms Act at Baldev Nagar police station. In his complaint given on Thursday, Satbir Singh of Amolak Ram Colony, Kurukshetra, said, “I supply dairy products in Chandigarh, Mohali, Zirakpur and Mohali. On Wednesday I was going towards my Mohali office. Around 9.30pm, I parked my car near Sultanpur median gap and went on the other side of the road to purchase a beer. When I came and sat in my car, three youths asked for a lift to Chandigarh. When I refused, one of the youths opened the door of my car and the other pointed a gun to my head. They hit me with the gun’s butt. Scared, I ran away and the trio fled with my car towards Chandigarh. I shouted for help and called the emergency number.” GPS in carSatbir told the media, “My son had installed a tracking application with the help of bluetooth in the car. With the application, we came to know that the miscreants had fled towards Chandigarh, but took a U-turn and then headed towards Uttar Pradesh via Karnal. At this moment, our car is being driven at 65kmph on the Agra Expressway. We have been giving inputs to the police, but they are not accepting the data as factual information.” Baldev Nagar police post in-charge said, “The CCTV camera footages of the area have been inspected, but we got no clues. The owner says there is a tracking application installed in the car, but our cyber cell teams say it isn’t. We have called the owner to police station for more details.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Gurugram: Parents allege girl slapped in.description: GURUGRAM: Parents of a two-and-half-year old girl filed a complaint against a playschool in Sector 51 on Thursday, alleging that the child was beaten by a staffer at the school premises. According to the complaint, the child, who has been going to the playschool for the past one year, was ill treated by a nanny, which the school authority denied and refused to take any action. “Our daughter informed us about the incident and to verify the same we went to the school. We checked the CCTV footage and found that she was slapped by the nanny as she refused to sleep during their scheduled nap-time,” said the girl’s parents. As both the parents work in different companies in the city, they had enrolled their daughter in a playschool. “My daughter usually stays at the school for the entire day and we had to trust the teachers and nanny for her safety,” the mother said. The parents also alleged that when they saw the footage it was clear that the school staff had slapped the child and also ill-treated others as well. Meanwhile, the school authorities have also approached police and filed a complaint against the parents stating that they had threatened and abused the school staff. “We have received complaints from both parties. An investigation is under way and we will talk to both of them to understand the problem,” said a senior police officer at Sector 50 police station. Yogi Adityanath.description: VARANASI: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath slammed Congress president Rahul Gandhi for suddenly showing concern for the poor and asked why he didn’t ensure a minimum income scheme for them during Congress-led UPA regime when his mother Sonia Gandhi acted as ‘super prime minister’ and had a say in everything. Targeting Congress announcement of minimum income scheme for poor on coming to power, Yogi said, “Congress led UPA was in power in Centre from 2004 to 2014. Everybody knows how Rahul and his mother (Sonia Gandhi) were influential in UPA regime. However, in UPA’s 10-year regime Congress never showed the kind of sympathy for poor, unemployed, farmers and women of country like it is showing now for Pakistan.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. When Algorithms Play Matchmaker.description: Ditching traditional faithfuls like astrology, matchmaking startups are putting their trust in artificial intelligence to find the ideal partners for young Indians. Why, even dating apps are turning to AI to enhance user experience like checking the authenticity of profiles that they are likely to see. But how good is deep tech in searching for a soulmate? And how much can you really rely on AI in matters of the heart?  Shubhra Pant  finds out In an episode of the British science-fiction series, ‘Black Mirror’, a couple is playing a simulation-based game. They are given multiple scenarios to test their compatibility, and see how their relationship would work. After a favourable outcome, the two decide to pair off and try their luck. While a Black Mirror might make it seem that looking for love is easy, humankind is still far off from such a sci-fi vision. However, companies in the matchmaking and dating business are already throwing in deep tech to better understand tender matters of the heart: after all, if algorithms can customise everything for you, from social media to travel, why not the search for a soulmate? The idea, to begin with, is simple — use data and algorithms to cut down on time spent on browsing profiles. Because, according to Pawan Gupta, co-founder of Betterhalf.ai, which calls itself a matchmaking app for professionals, Indians go through roughly 10,000 profiles every year, spending around 1,000 hours on dating or matchmaking apps. That’s an average of 28 profiles per day. No wonder the percentage of online swipes to offline dates remains very low.  A kundli for the tech age Betterhalf’s primary objective, says Gupta, is to significantly bring down the number of profiles men and women must browse in their pursuit of matrimony. Artificial intelligence is a tool that can help them achieve that. "Hence, we use big data and AI to help people find better-suited people on our platform," he adds. Unlike a typical matrimonial portal, Betterhalf provides a list of possible matches but doesn’t let you surf. Gupta, interestingly, came upon the idea for an algorithm-based matchmaker when searching for his own partner. He went on to marry her. So, how does it work? Well, after logging in, a user takes a survey in which s/he is asked questions on topics as different as values and beliefs, intellectual levels and social skills, relationships and emotional preferences. The information collated from the questionnaire is clubbed with a separate cache of data collected from surveys of those who are happily married. Then algorithms take a deep dive and fish out what they believe are the best matches for you. As Manoj Singh, an infrastructure developer with a leading financial company who found his soulmate online says, "It isn’t easy to describe why you like someone and why you dislike someone – it is an internal process which is difficult to put into words." So, sometimes, you just trust the AI and see what happens. Betterhalf currently has around 14,000 (approx.) users in the National Capital Region, 11,000 in Mumbai and Bangalore, and 6,500 in Pune and Hyderabad. Eighty per cent of those registered on the app are from metros. Clearly, plenty of urban Indians are happy to confide in AI to make their life decision for them.  Date with data Figures from data analyst Tracxn show 261 online dating and matchmaking apps were founded in India between 2001 and 2019. And while both Banihal and Betterhalf are new kids on the block serving niches, even established players like OkCupid and Bumble are turning to AI to enhance user experience. Global dating app OkCupid, part of the Match Group (which also owns Tinder), is a case in point, working on the principle of matching users based on their answers to a series of questions — a function powered by AI. Like Betterhalf, there’s Banihal.com, which also relies on AI to arrange matches. It also asks users to fill in an exhaustive questionnaire, in which they are required to reveal their financial background, family’s monthly income, and likes and dislikes (among other details). "A great match is when you don’t have to compromise on any of the aspects, such as religion, culture and family," says Ishdeep Sawhney, the California-based founder of Banihal. The website caters mainly to Delhi, Mumbai, Bangalore, Hyderabad and Pune, but also has users from Tier-1 and Tier-2 cities in India (and from the US, too). "When we make this decision, we don’t have hard limits like, the age (of the partner) has to be 27 – because, depending on all the other unique aspects we like, the age can be 28 as well," Sawhney explains. Banihal, he clarifies, restricts itself to professionals aged between 25 and 30 since an AI engine can only be trained for a certain subset, and cannot be randomly applied to everyone. And, once singles have connected with each other, Banihal has a 90% success rate, claims Sawhney (incidentally, on the app, compatibility is represented by three gold rings, while the best matches are distinguished by a diamond ring).  Math of a match For these tech platforms, the key is to save users from the endless cycle of searches. After all, the process of browsing and swiping, does get exhausting after a while. "The problem is that no one really has the time to go through thousands of profiles and talk to hundreds of people to go on a date – and even after that, there is no guarantee of these dates working out," says a 28-year-old MBA graduate, who requested not to be named. "I once matched with a man who thought I was too opinionated for a lady when his profile suggested that he was a liberal and feminist," she added. Melissa Hobley, chief marketing officer at OkCupid, says the app allows people to connect at a deeper level, through beliefs and interests, for example, rather than just a photo and location. It does this by employing an algorithm centred on machine learning. "The idea behind the app’s algorithm is to take over the conventional task of being introduced by friends or family in the digital medium," she told TOI. "The deep-math AI has two key differences — one, the system allows people to connect beyond their social circles, and two, as a non-judgmental platform, users can be their true self and be honest about relationship expectations without the fear of social stigma, making for more meaningful matches," she added. And this holds true for every type of relationship, not just heteronormative, according to Hobley. Thus, sex, gender, identity and preference can be shared directly, and the algorithm will present a relevant match. Meanwhile, Bumble, which is partially owned by Priyanka Chopra, believes artificial intelligence can make the app a safer place for its users. Earlier this month, Bumble launched Private Detector, a feature that can capture images in real time with 98% accuracy. Once a lewd image is shared within a chat, the Private Detector will automatically blur that image and alert the user they have been sent something inappropriate. Users can then decide, according to a Bumble spokesperson, whether to view the image or block it. They can also report the image to its team of moderators.  AIs and nays But more personal information on the web, in times when concerns on invasion of privacy, snooping by apps and data collection by online companies, isn’t always a comforting thought. Some users, for instance, find the questions asked by matchmaking websites intrusive. "While I understand the need for most questions, I don’t understand the need to ask about family income and caste. On the one hand, we are trying to transcend caste and class boundaries, on the other these apps focus a lot on them," rues Urvashi Kingrani, an event manager based in Gurugram. Besides, points out Kingrani, AI assumes that people with similar interests and attributes are likely to get along, which isn’t necessarily true in real life. "Often, totally opposite people make great partners," she adds. Further, most apps don’t score very high when it comes to inclusiveness, despite most claiming to serve the LGBTQ community. A Delhi resident disclosed she had sampled many apps but only one worked. "I tried one app that had an option for LGBT but nothing for transsexuals and pansexuals. In my opinion, there has to be more freedom to define oneself on the app, and what they are looking for." Evidently, there will be no dearth of examples when artificial intelligence is no match for the heart (and mind), for all the permutations that algorithms can throw up. Yet, with more and more Indians ending up on dating and matchmaking sites, there’s no reason to disbelieve the marriage of tech and tradition won’t (or can’t) work either. Because, finally, it’s not about how AI uses you, it’s how you use AI. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

\u2018I don\u2019t watch cricket but an.description: After the US Ice Hockey team upset the mighty Soviet team in the semi-final of the 1980 Winter Olympics, a sports magazine ran a cover story featuring a picture of the American players celebrating without any explanatory captions or headline. “It didn’t need it. Everyone in America knew what happened,” explained the photographer. It’s not as if ice hockey was a popular game in the US but such was the hype for the game – played at the height of the Cold War – that even Americans who had never watched ice hockey before or didn’t even know the rules tuned in for it. Many Indians would find this scenario familiar. Because today, they will do the same as India and Pakistan face off in an epic Cricket World Cup game (unless the rain has other plans). Cricket might be a religion in India, but there still are plenty of atheists around, many of whom don’t even understand cricket, let alone follow it. And they only end their aversion to the game on one particular occasion – when India plays Pakistan. The reasons range from peer pressure to a heightened sense of patriotism and even adherence to social decorum. ‘Cricket-crazy family leaves me no choice’Vamini Sethi, management consultant, 33, GurgaonI will watch the game as my cricket-crazy family will leave me with no choice. It will be on TV all day and all the discussions in the house will be about the match. I don’t follow cricket because I find it too time-consuming and overhyped. There are other sports like hockey, kabaddi that bring glory to our country but go unnoticed. I have nothing against the game; it brings the entire nation together. But it has so many fans, I’m sure it can do with one less. ‘Don’t usually have time to watch cricket, but will make time today’Ashvarya Sharma, homemaker, 52, DelhiIt’s not that I hate cricket but since I am a homemaker, I have to keep running around doing chores and can’t spend the whole day sitting and watching cricket. But TV pe bhi toh wahi chalta hai din bhar toh dekhna hi padta hai. However, the India-Pakistan game is different. I watch it by choice. It’s not just cricket; it’s almost war-like. The sentiment is different. In fact, today I plan to finish my chores early. Kitchen ki bhi chutti hai uss din. I don't miss a single ball of any India-Pakistan match. ‘Will watch the match because it is the patriotic thing to do’Ananya Pandey, communication professional, 29, DelhiI really never had anyone in my family who was an ardent cricket fan or watched it for fun, so I never found any company to watch the game or develop a taste for it. The last game I watched was the 2011 World Cup final that India won. I watched because it was a special occasion and it felt like the patriotic thing to do. Similarly, I will watch the India-Pakistan match today because it’s a different rush altogether. As clichéd as it may sound, as an Indian, any Indo-Pak discussion catches my attention. Specially post the Pulwama attack and the increasing political tensions, I’d like to see how this tension will affect the performances of both the teams. Also, on a lighter note, my boss – a die-hard cricket fan – has instructed me to watch this match and cheer for India. 'After balakot strike, anything India-Pak will attract me'Rajat Kothari, banker, 38, NoidaI don’t follow cricket but an India-Pakistan game is not cricket. I don’t understand the rules and the jargon of cricket and prefer football, to be honest. At least, it’s played by more than a dozen countries in the world. But when I will sit with my friends and family to watch the game today, I won’t be watching cricket, I feel I will be supporting India against Pakistan, on all fronts. After the skirmishes recently and the Balakot Air Strike, the atmosphere is such that anything India-Pakistan will attract my attention. This will be my first ever cricket match and I hope India wins. ‘The only way to socialise today’Ishita Mathur, teacher, 22, GhaziabadI will watch it because it’s a great way to socialise. Today, cricket will be the only topic of conversation. It just doesn’t seem right to ignore that or not be a part of the discourse. So, I will join my family in front of the TV today and watch the game. The reason I don’t watch cricket is because I find it boring. I prefer other team sports like football and basketball. They seem more participative and active. In cricket, it seems only the bowler and batsmen are doing something at a given time while the others are passively involved. 'Flatmates will suck me into the frenzy'Tsering Tashi, research scholar, 29, DelhiI will have to watch it. What else do you do when everyone around you is crazy about it? I live in a flat with three other cricket-crazy boys and they will watch the game. So, I will be party to the frenzy. I grew up watching and playing football and for me, that is the beautiful game. Cricket is just a colonial hangover, not a sport. I have managed to avoid all the other India matches in the World Cup so far but the hype around the India-Pakistan match is such that you get sucked into the maelstrom somehow. Match tickets being sold for Rs 4 lakhThe tickets for the clash which will take place at the Old Trafford Stadium – which has a capacity of 20000 – were sold out within hours of the ticket window opening. There were half a million ticket applications for the match, meaning the stadium could have been sold out 20 times over. And now, those who have bought the tickets are earning more by re-selling them. One website, is now buying tickets from fans and is reselling them for prices ranging from approximately Rs 20,000 to Rs 60,000. According to the UK media, tickets are being sold in the black market for anything from £5,000 (Rs 4.4 lakh) to £2,500 (Rs 2.2 lakh) Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Girl commits suicide in MDU hostel.description: ROHTAK: A 24-year-old girl student from Meham district on Tuesday night committed suicide by hanging from the ceiling fan in Maharshi Dayanand University (MDU) girl’s hostel. The deceased has been identified as Gangandeep Kaur, who was a student of M. Pharmacy (final year) in the university. Professor Rajesh Dhankhar, chief warden of the girl’s hostel, told the media that they came to know about the incident on Wednesday after she did not come for breakfast. When hostel staff went to her room, she was found hanging from the ceiling fan. Kaur was good at academics and was happy with her life, said one of her classmates who met media persons outside the hostel. "We met her on Tuesday and there seemed to be no such issue which could force her to take the extreme step. However, she was little emotional and used to take things to heart. But there was no big issue as such going on in her life,” said another classmate. Sources, however, said that she was in tension over submission of her thesis to the department and had shared the concern with some of her friends. The MDU administration said that the deceased’s parents were informed about the development and they were co-operating with the police. An FSL team also visited the spot for investigation. The police said that they were probing it after registering a case under Section 174 of the CrPC (procedure for investigation into unnatural death cases). Arvind Kejriwal.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said that Congress President Rahul Gandhi has refused to forge an alliance with the AAP for the Lok Sabha polls in the national capital. Full coverage: Lok Sabha electionsTalking to reporters at the airport here, the AAP leader said he had met Gandhi recently and the Congress leader had refused to “join hands with the AAP”. Asked about Congress' Delhi unit president Sheila Dikshit's remarks that Kejriwal never approached her for an alliance, the chief minister said, “We have met Rahul Gandhi. Dikshit is not that important leader.” Kejriwal has been urging the Congress to stitch an alliance in Delhi for the Lok Sabha polls to keep the BJP away from power. Leaders in the Delhi unit of the Congress were divided over the issue of alliance with Dikshit and her three working presidents opposing it, party sources had said. A top source in the party had recently said that chances of alliance were "slim" considering its long term repercussions in Delhi. "The biggest question is how will Congress face the AAP in Assembly elections due in 2020 after the tie up. Also, the party does not gain much politically as it is being offered only 2-3 seats by Kejriwal," the source had said. Congress had drawn a blank in the 2014 parliamentary elections in Delhi. The talk of alliance was fuelled by the fact that the Congress and AAP had jointly polled more votes than the BJP that had walked away with all the seven seats in the national capital. Delhi has 7 Lok Sabha seats and it will go to polls on May 12. In Video:Congress refused to forge alliance with AAP for LS polls: KejriwalDownload The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Gurugram: Two more arrested for gas agen.description: GURUGRAM: Two more persons were arrested on Saturday in connection with the robbery of Rs 37 lakh from the cashier of a gas agency in November, 2018. Police have recovered Rs 1 lakh from their possession. The police have earlier arrested three members of the Delhi-based gang and now with the arrest of two members, the entire gang has been busted. Police commissioner Muhammad Akil said the gang was active in the NCR for some time and they have been involved in several cases of murder, loot and robberies. “The gang was notorious for executing big loots and robberies,” said Akil. On November 26, 2018, an unknown bike-borne youth had snatched Rs 37 lakh from the cashier of Urvashi gas agency on gunpoint in South City I. A case was registered in this case in Sector 40 police station. The gas agency belongs to BJP district spokesperson and local councillor Kuldeep Yadav's family. Sushil Lathar, cashier of Urvashi Enterprises, was leaving for a bank to deposit Rs 37 lakh in cash. Three men came on a bike and snatched the cash bag after threatening to shoot him. The other three members were arrested in December last year. Later in December police had managed to arrest three members of gang — Sombir, Ishwar and Sachin alias Chottu and recovered two country made pistols and 8 bullets from their possession. Crime unit of 39 on Saturday arrested two more accused from Delhi in connection with the case. The accused were identified as Saunny and Ajay both from Delhi. They were produced before court and taken into five day police remand. During interrogation they revealed that Sombir was master mind of the gang. Sombir met one Surender in jail and he discussed with him plan to start a gas agency. After coming out of the jail Surnder introduce Sombir to manager of Urvashi gas agency. After witnessing large transaction of cash at Urvashi gas agency he decided to loot the manager. Police said Ajay was involved in conducting recce of the gas agency and its manager before executing the crime. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

50 Karnal farmers get notices for sowing.description: KARNAL: The deputy director, agriculture, Karnal, has issued notices to 50 farmers of the district for transplanting paddy before the fixed date (June 15), thus violating the Haryana Preservation of Sub-Soil Water Act, 2009. The department has uprooted the crop transplanted in around 50 acres. “The department had fixed June 15 for paddy transplantation, but 50 farmers sowed it earlier in violation of the Soil Water Conservation Act 2009,” said Dr Sunil Kumar, SDO, agriculture department, Karnal. “We had issued notices to more than 50 farmers for transplanting paddy crop early and asked them to destroy it on their own. Out of them, 19 farmers had uprooted their paddy according to the department guidelines. But when the remaining farmers did not do so on their own, so we have sent the proposal to the deputy commissioner to impose a fine on them,” he added. The SDO said paddy was cultivated on 1.72 lakh hectares in Karnal, but now the agriculture department has decided to reduce the area under paddy by 12,000 hectares in the district and shift the area under maize. He said to promote cultivation of maize, the department would give an incentive of Rs 2,000 per acre to the farmers. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Urmila Matondkar.description: MUMBAI: The Congress on Friday nominated actress Urmila Matondkar and former Lok Sabha speaker Meira Kumar from Mumbai North and Bihar's Sasaram parliamentary constituencies respectively. The party renominated its sitting MP Ranjet Ranjan from Supaul in Bihar, as it released a list of another 12 candidates for the general elections. With this list, the Congress has so far nominated 305 Lok Sabha candidates. Urmila Matondkar to contest from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency on a Congress ticket.… https://t.co/JweKWNh1FN— ANI (@ANI) 1553836382000It also changed its candidate in Uttar Pradesh's Maharajganj by now fielding Supriya Shrinate in place of Tanushree Tripathi, the daughter of jailed politician Amarmani Tripathi, after facing widespread criticism. "The Congress central election committee has approved the candidature of Urmila Matondkar as party candidate to contest the ensuing general elections from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency in Maharashtra," a party statement said. Matondkar had joined the Congress after meeting Rahul Gandhi on Wednesday and had later said that she was "here to stay". Meira Kumar have been contesting from her Sasaram parliamentary constituency for many years but had lost in the 2014 Lok Sabha polls. Apart from Supriya Shrinate, in the list of 12 candidates released by the party, four are from Bihar and seven from Odisha. The Congress also released a list of 20 candidates for Odisha Assembly election.
